title: No, "main" and "one trick pony" aren't the same thing.
body:
This refers to the frontpage post.
Yes, being a OTP means complete dedication to that champ, by definition, It means you can't do anything else, or at least not even close to the level of your main.
A "main" is simply the champ you're the most confortable with and that you use the most. And yes, you can have several ones, even for a single role.

As a fighting game fanboy, I feel the need to point something out and drop some terminology. 

You typically don't have more than one main. You can have one main and several "subs," but never more than one main. Your main is the one you feel MOST comfortable playing. Your subs are the ones you also feel comfortable playing, but they don't feel as natural to play as your main, but are still something you feel confident enough to pick if your main gets a bad pick, gets banned, or you just kinda wanna play something else for a while.

For example, in Blazblue, I'm a Noel main and a Ragna sub. I'm the most comfortable playing Noel, but I can always pick Ragna whenever I feel like it. (In fighting games, its a lot of work to learn a character, unlike league where it takes maybe 30 minutes tops, so its not uncommon to not have many subs at all.)

In league, I'm a Riven main, and a Shen, Leona, Varus, Morgana (mid) and Shyvana sub. Most of those subs are my go to pick for any different role, since I couldn't viably pick Riven into ADC or Support, so I'd pick Varus or Leona for that. However, any chance I get, I'm playing Riven. 

So yea, kinda useless knowledge, but it helps clear up the difference between a main and a OTP in a completely different way.

Eh, it's a bit different in league, because not every champion can go into every lane. My (strongest) mains are Quinn, Xerath, Nautilus, and Leona, for ADC, mid, top, and support respectively.

For fighting games, you can technically have one character that you can stick with for everything. Whereas in League, it's either highly ineffective or straight impossible

As I said, OTP is the good name for that, since it contains "one" in it. "Main" can be about a subgroup, not necessarily about a single element.
So, in my case, for example, it'll be "which of my main 3 champs do I feel like playing now", or 4 if you count as a 4th main the sum of all the cheese picks I sometimes play.

OTP for me is strictly for ranked.

For example, I literally only play darius ranked, unless if he gets banned for whatever reason (which at least in my games, is rather rare, like, exceedingly rare).

However, in normals and (obviously because I cannot control champ select) ARAMs, I won't play darius all the time necessarily, and I don't think that strips me of OTP status.

I'm pretty sure that qualifies you has having a Darius main rather than being a Darius OTP.

If you play a lot of ranked, you'd naturally play your main a lot more than most other champions because ranked is where you'd want to win the most. Your main is your best champ, so naturally you'd play him significantly more than other champions.

Normals is when you play a lot of your "fun champions". Champions that you aren't necessarily good on but enjoy how they play, and you don't play them all the time as a result. By playing other champions that aren't your main, you've given yourself proof that you aren't an OTP.

A main is the champion you play the most. You can't have more than one main, completely defeats the meaning of the word. Your main can change over time but you only have one current main. 

One trick pony is someone who only plays their main champion and doesn't have a champion pool.

As I explained elsewhere, "main" in the language can be attributed to a subgroup in the entire population, not necessarily to a single individual.

So, in my case, my main is 3 champs. {{champion:133}} {{champion:75}} {{champion:50}} when I have to pick (unless it's ranked and counters, y'know) I always think to myself "le phun kitey, le phun smash or le phun drain?".

Once again, a main is the champion you play the most. If you play all three champions the same, you don't have a main. It's like saying "What is your favorite color" and you say "I like blue, red and uhhh...green". You don't have a favorite, you like three different colors the same. A main doesn't refer to a subgroup of a population in League (Or any context that I'm aware of), it refers to the #1 champion you play. Saying I have 3 mains or I have 20 mains just makes you sound silly to other people. You have a champion pool you like to play and don't main any particular champion is the correct terminology.

The concept of "can't" play anything else is kind of wobbly in league. By your definition, there is no such thing as an OTP, spare perhaps brand new players that have only played 1 champion ever. Like, an OTP diamond level Le Blanc mid could probably play Ahri at gold level, through sheer game knowledge,   rotations, exploitation of mistakes, etc.

There are a 'lot' of skills that transfer.  However, in ranked, I consider myself  an OTP (or did, recently been fanning out due to sheer necessity), by the definition of "being able to play at/above the Rank I'm at".
